body_html: Only just spotted this when browsing the PyTorch forums! I implemented a simple version just for my own needs here, but a properly designed layer would be nice. As you mentioned, I think picking new noise variables and setting them to 0 are pretty much the only things that you need to add. Perhaps you could have zero noise be triggered when calling .eval() and picking new noise when calling .train(), but definitely the ability to sample new noise variables needs to be available to the user.

body: Only just spotted this when browsing the PyTorch forums! I implemented a simple version just for my own needs [here](https://github.com/Kaixhin/NoisyNet-A3C/blob/master/model.py#L10-L37), but a properly designed layer would be nice. As you mentioned, I think picking new noise variables and setting them to 0 are pretty much the only things that you need to add. Perhaps you could have zero noise be triggered when calling `.eval()` and picking new noise when calling `.train()`, but definitely the ability to sample new noise variables needs to be available to the user.
